"Because of the inactive lifestyle and stressful life, many people suffer from lifestyle diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, etc. Fit India Movement can encourage people to eat healthy food and maintain their physical and mental condition."

"With high-quality advertising and marketing practices, junk food manufacturers manipulate children to buy their food. This Fit India movement will make children think about the negative consequences of junk food. Therefore, this movement will encourage children to eat healthy food."

"Some parents put too much stress on children to study. They send their children to classes after school or simply make them sit down to do their homework or forget the importance of free time to play. This movement has the potential to change its mind and, therefore, they can encourage their children to come out and play."

"This movement has the potential to make more people embrace traditional forms of Indian martial art like Kathi Samu, Musti Yudha, etc, and traditional dance forms and also healthy Indian snacks. And as a by-product, it can lead to job creation."
"The motivation to maintain physical fitness should begin as early as childhood. But in India, many schools lack playgrounds. Lack of playgrounds can cause children to adopt inactive lifestyles."

"Fit India Movement" may not reach people living below the poverty line. To maintain a healthy lifestyle, physical activity and nutritious foods are needed. But in India, many people still suffer from malnutrition and some do not have access to safe drinking water. Thus, without addressing the issue of poverty and lack of access to affordable nutritious food, a portion of the Indian population will not be able to benefit from this movement."

"Some people are already focusing on physical fitness. We can observe this with the increasing number of fitness startups. But it's a small proportion of people. In general, many people want to maintain an active lifestyle, but all they need is some encouragement. So this movement constantly reminds people to focus on fitness goals just as Swachh Bharat reminds us of the importance of keeping our environment clean."

"Since the invention of machines, the value of workers has diminished. They are designed to work to support the machines. As a result, the work revolves around machines and not humans. Workers are obliged to work permanently with the machine. "

"People are now involved in trolling and cyberbullying. Hide behind the devices gives them the courage to harass others, which they cannot face face to face. This is the deterioration of moral values."

"Some companies are building strategies to use their apps for longer, to keep us dependent on their apps and devices so they can show us ads. And also they can use our data to manipulate our decisions for their profits. These strategies transform humans into simple targets."

"Industrialization has increased working hours. Workers are in inhumane conditions. Humans cannot work and concentrate continuously like machines. Move quickly until today, we have technology devices to check how many hours we actually work. Some companies want to be connected 24 hours a day through emails and messages. It makes people feel less human."

"Our decision-making skills are also affected, as we now ask search engines to know what is best. We depend on the knowledge base of the Internet even in offices to complete the work within reach. This affects cognitive skills (thinking, reading, learning, remembering and reason), which is an essential quality of man."

"Many face-to-face communications are also replaced by virtual interactions. Many people now live in virtual homes, which is the smartphone. As the need to speak with one another diminishes, the ability to communicate with one another, which is a fundamental quality of living beings, decreases."

"We are increasingly dependent on technological devices to guide us. For example, we keep reminders on smartphones and google questions for answers. We underestimate activities that require intelligence to technology. Thinking, remembering things and analyzing are essential qualities of humans. Too much dependence on technology makes us less human."

"Thanks to technology, people maintain and improve their relationships with friends, family and loved ones. Many people also connect with each other to help the needy and inspire each other. So now we have better tools to build human bonds."

Technology allows us to work from home. This facility helps employers better understand employees. Many companies now add elements to the work culture with the help of technology to make employees feel important.

"This bill gave exclusive powers to the "National Investigation Agency" (NIA). The NIA may detain any person under UAPA without the prior authorization of the Government of the State. It is against federalism, which is guaranteed by the constitution of India."

"Labelling organisations as terrorist organisations and individuals as terrorists are quite different. If a person is designated as a terrorist, he or she will face social exclusion and will be deprived of means of subsistence, even if he or she has proved otherwise. The consequences will be irreversible. For example, in 2016 alone, 67% of cases ended in acquittal, which means that they are probably innocent."

"If anyone is reserved under UAPA, the burden of proving their innocence rests with them. This new amendment allows the government to seize its property. So how will they pay the legal fees to prove their innocence, if they are falsely accused?"

"This will give the central government more police powers. It is possible to misuse the possibility of designating individuals as terrorists. For example, recently, several civil activists are called urban Naxals. If anyone opposes the government, he will be vulnerable to being called a terrorist. Because this amendment made it easier to call anyone a terrorist."

"The terrorism of wolves alone is increasingly threatened. Lonely wolf terrorists have no association with terrorist organizations, but they alone commit terrorist attacks. This new amendment to the UAP is likely to curb the terrorism of wolves alone."

"To prevent human rights violations, a four-stage review is added. India has not begun to designate individuals as terrorists. The United States, the European Union and China also have this provision."

"So far, only organizations were designated as terrorist organizations, but not individuals. The gap is that individuals of banned organizations form new organizations and carry out terrorist activities. This draft amendment to the Law on the Prevention of Illegal Activities allows the government to designate individuals as terrorists, thus preventing terrorist attacks."
There is a need for vigorous action against terrorism in the context of increasing threats from terrorists. It is therefore necessary to strengthen UAPA.

"At present, India does not have a well-developed data security infrastructure. On the other hand, developed countries already have an efficient infrastructure. Thus, rushing to the location of data may not be a wise step. Because in the absence of an efficient infrastructure, data are subject to cyber attacks. And the risk here is serious because it is financial data. But as laws are passed, it is very difficult to develop efficient infrastructure at a faster pace."

"The storage of data in India entails higher operational costs for payment system operators. Because in other countries, they have cheaper alternatives. And also for cross-border transactions, they need to store data in two places, which increases costs. It is likely that these additional costs can be passed on to consumers."

"The laws of location of data lead to the establishment of several data centres locally. This will create many jobs and help the country's economy immensely. It will also stimulate innovation on the ground, leading to low-cost solutions."

"While investigating crimes, it will be necessary to access payment data. If the data are stored abroad, it is very difficult to obtain permission from that country to access the data. This leads to delays in the resolution of crimes. If the data is stored here in our country, this problem will be avoided."

"India is a large consumer market for many foreign companies. Thus, India and other developing countries realize the economic value of the data and the importance of the location of the data. With the location of the data, national companies and the economy of the country will benefit. And we can also ensure data security."

"Data are considered a "new form of wealth". In general, companies use the data to understand consumers' requirements and also to influence their behaviour. New products can be developed by analysing data to meet consumer needs. The data therefore have an economic value. In general, developed countries benefit from this opportunity thanks to their well-developed infrastructure. "

"We are in a globalized world. At present, the world operates on the free movement of people, goods, services and data. Legislation on the location of data seems to be part of protectionist policies, which poses a threat to the free flow of data."

"The United States is against the laws on the location of data. Recently at the G20 summit, Donald Trump, the President of the United States spoke out against the location of data. Its position is natural because it increases the operational costs of U.S. companies. Bilateral relations between India and the United States are important for both countries because we are linked to the export and import of computer services, professionals and goods, etc. So imposing data localization laws without threatening Indo-American relations is another challenge."
We can ensure the confidentiality of the data by locating the data.
The location of the data can lead to the government's monitoring of its citizens.
"The location of data is important for data sovereignty, which means that citizens' data should be held by the respective governments and not by other countries."

The law is very clear that RTI does not only deal with government agencies. It is also for non-governmental organizations that are substantially funded and controlled by the government. There are many subsidies (including tax exemptions) available to political parties, which are therefore substantially financed by the Government.
"Political parties are independent bodies, they do not have to be accountable to the public. They have not been established by the Constitution or by an Act of Parliament."

"The ITR Act states that wherever there is a public interest, these organizations must be transparent and fall within the scope of the Act. There are now a number of private organisations, whether partially or entirely funded; schools, hospitals, etc. which are under the Access to Information Act and not just government organizations."
The Income Tax Act and the Electoral Commission contain adequate provisions that allow people to have the information they want.

"The ITR Act contains provisions under section 8 that refer to the notion of competitive interest. Certain exemptions are provided in cases where it can be demonstrated that disclosure of information may adversely affect the party's competitive advantage. This is not only a problem with political parties, but also with a large number of government and private bodies."

"Political financing is believed to be the source of corruption. Citizens have the right to know where political parties collect these funds, how they spend them and on the basis of their decisions. Crony's capitalism will be severely restrained if political parties are subject to the RTI law."

"Under the IT Act, political parties do not need to disclose donations that are less than INR 20,000. An informal study conducted in 2010 of 6 key political parties shows that they raised Rs 700 crore. 95% of the amount was increased by amounts less than Rs 20,000. It is very likely that political parties will use this gap to their advantage."
"Political parties declare certain promises in their manifestos. After being elected, citizens have the right to know why the promises made by political parties have not been honoured."

"Political parties are at the heart of the functioning of democracy. Political parties form the government. Government policies are then governed by the ideology of the party. Thus, it becomes essential that political parties be subject to the RTI."

"If political parties fall under the RTI, this will affect their internal functioning. Rivals can use RTI to blend. Moreover, as political parties are not directly linked to the public, an RTI would be invalid."

"Overall, the Indians view educational institutions as employment machines, we expect to get unemployed and find a job. We do not realize that we will need to improve our skills to become worthy of employment. This is why more than 80% of engineers are unemployable and the figures are even worse for non-engineers."

" Although we have established national institutes over the past 40 years, we have not invested in maintaining their standards. Funds are needed for quality education. Even the best Indian institutes lack infrastructure, laboratories, resources, etc. And even what is available is just to pass the students to the exam and remain inactive for the rest of the time."
"Today, no problem has a single solution and no new technology is linked to a single discipline. We need multiple contributions from several disciplines and our institutes have failed to do so."

"Indian students perform brilliantly when they travel to different countries in the field of research. This means that we do not lack talent, we lack infrastructure and a healthy environment for our lively minds."

"We did not pay our teachers at the level of what their counterparts earn in other countries. As a result, people are reluctant to teach as a career. Nor have we been able to attract foreign faculties to our institutes."

"It takes time to achieve excellence in anything. Thanks to their degree, students gain so much knowledge in the relevant field. Thus, it is easier for employers to train these students to meet industrial requirements."
Any skill can be learned and mastered even if we do not have a diploma in this field. And programming is no exception.

"Even if someone has an IT degree, they need to learn so much to get into IT work, because there is a gap between industry standards and skills that are taught in engineering colleges. In addition, as technology is constantly evolving, even if someone has prepared for industrial standards in their degree, they need to learn new technologies at all times to remain relevant in the labour market. Thus, as the learning curve will be there even for IT students, non-IT students can also learn these things and can enter IT jobs."

"The number of jobs in information technology is growing rapidly as a result of the technological revolution. There will therefore be more jobs in the field of information technology. And if recruiters are very strict on the degree, they can miss a great pool of talents, which are of a non-IT past."

"Now we have so many online course platforms through which we can learn almost any expert skill. We can also obtain certificates if we pass the tests. Thus, as Tim Cook said, a four - year - old diploma seems old and traditional. "

"In many engineering schools in India, we can easily pass the subjects even if we don't have a lot of knowledge in these subjects. This is why many companies are not able to find appropriate talent, even if there are so many eligible graduates. So the desire to become an expert in the field is more important than a diploma. "
"If a non-IT student has chosen to start a career in computer science, his efforts to graduate will be in vain."

"Although the new programming languages replace the old ones, the basic concepts are the same for almost all programming languages. So whoever has a degree in coding will have an advantage over the student of a non-IT training."

"People change careers even after working in a field for several years because our interests change.So when someone can do it while having so many personal responsibilities, it is much easier for young people to learn a new skill. "

"Variable remuneration certainly increases the productivity of employees. High-performing people feel well-paid and rewarded for their efforts, while those with insufficient performance also feel motivated to improve."

"In variable pay plans, employees feel satisfied and motivated by their work. They believe that they are an integral part of the organization, that they recognize them as part of its growth and that they value their efforts."

"Variable remuneration helps retain valuable employees. This helps to retain good talent for long periods of time and, as a result, reduces spending on hiring new talent. This ensures the stability of the organization."

" It has been found that it is difficult to keep employees in a period of relaxation when they are subject to variable pay schemes. Workers who receive commissions do well when business is good, but they hurt when business is bad. In times of slowing down of business, even the best sellers could have difficulty making enough sales to make a decent living. If the market is slow and commissioned workers cannot earn enough, they can look for other job opportunities. In times of weakness, fixed wages can be more effective in preventing employees from leaving for other occasions."

"Variable remuneration can lead to unhealthy competition between employees. They become less willing to help each other. Team cooperation can be negatively affected. In the long term, relations between colleagues can become bitter. While, in fixed remuneration schemes, employees are able to maintain cordial relations in the office."

"Most of the time, sales jobs have a variable component. This could have a negative impact on the employee's attitude towards clients. They can force customers irrationally just to make profits for themselves. They could overestimate the price for customers just to make more profit. While a fixed salary employee would maintain healthy and positive relationships with clients, which would allow him or her to find the right balance in his or her approach."

"The huge data we produce every day is analyzed and fed into our devices through algorithms that we end up giving more and more control of our lives to gadgets. We can feel that we receive all these services free of charge, but they come at the price of our precious time and attention."

"With all the data and algorithms, our applications and gadgets, without our conscious knowledge, make decisions for us. Decision-making is (was) one of the qualities that made humans different from others."

"After a daily shift of 10 hours from Monday to Friday, most of us prefer to stay at home during the holidays. We surround ourselves with laptops, TV and mobiles and use them in cycles for Netflix, sports, social networks, etc. (Thinking we're relaxing) rather than going out. We prefer and are more comfortable with online conversation instead of talking to people for real. There are fewer significant relationships today due to all the above factors. We started to prefer isolation."

"Nuclear technology is a very efficient alternative to non-renewable energy resources. But we have always chosen to move forward with more and more types of nuclear warheads. The same applies to almost all other inventions. Similarly, although initially AI promised us better lives, because of AI, we began to lose our basic human qualities."
"We've started to lose our basic human habits and instincts, and we're actually governed by devices and applications."

"As Yuval Noah Harari says, what we need now is morals and spirituality. Morality is reducing suffering in the world. And spirituality is questioning and seeking answers. Religions just give us answers and no field of questions."

"Religion has served its purpose of uniting people, establishing structures in society and developing trust and cooperation. But in the 21st century, we are growing towards objective realities, and religion is an inter-subjective reality and now the only thing it does is to create differences in the world, to wash people's brains, to develop animosity for other beliefs, and to provide rituals that are only shortcuts to become a good person. (A Muslim can pray 5 times a day; a Hindu can pray every day for hours in temples; a Christian can go to church every day, but still be involved in immoral activities."

"In the past, every unknown thing dealt with religious beliefs. But now science and technology have taken over. We know the reasons for drought, earthquakes, windstorms, etc. They are scientific phenomena, not the wrath of the gods."

"Because of their technological nature, neo-banks do not need physical bank branches, which helps them to save on overhead costs (the operating cost of the business). Thus, neo-banks are able to offer customers lower fees and higher interest rates on control and savings accounts."

"People don't trust neo-banks so much because they don't have a physical presence, which makes them a risk to customers in case of problems or challenges. Customer service in person may seem more trustworthy for customers."

Technological literacy is still very low in India. Traditional banks can meet the banking requirements of less technologically informed customers or people in rural areas of the country who prefer face-to-face interaction with the manager.
"Commercial banks are helping to create credit, leading to an increase in production, employment and consumer spending, which contributes to the growth of the economy."
"As neo-banks are fully digital, they operate 24 hours a day and their services are accessible at any time. They are easy to access from anywhere through a smartphone."

"Fintech companies can open specialized neo-banks that target a specific type of customer. For example, LXME aims to become the first Indian Neo bank for women, which will offer product solutions that meet women's specific financial needs and emotional preferences."
"5G in the banking sector will bring the necessary financial inclusion to rural and remote populations in India, for whom access to a physical bank is not possible."

"The low latency of 5G will allow the inclusion of education in remote areas of India, where children will be able to access good quality education at home without any disconnect between them and their preferred tutor. In addition, 5G will make it possible to use new technologies such as AR and RV for more immersive learning in schools and colleges."

"5G will significantly increase the number of networks that can be connected, handling up to a trillion Internet terminals of objects, which will allow machines and humans in a factory to communicate smoothly, making the company more efficient and reducing the possibility of error."

"The government will be able to improve its governance and boost its India Digital Initiative, which aims to ensure that government services are made available electronically to citizens, which will enable the country to develop digital technology capabilities."
"Hydrogen is flammable and can cause fires or explosions. So, it's not completely safe yet."
"If hydrogen production uses fossil fuels, it can be counterproductive. It is therefore important to use renewable energy to produce hydrogen."

"Hydrogen cell vehicles do not emit greenhouse gases. This helps to combat climate change. Since many countries are opting for the energy transition, clean hydrogen vehicles and other alternative fuel vehicles can pave the way for sustainable transport. Moreover, since these vehicles do not emit greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, they can to a large extent reduce air pollution."
"The prices of fossil fuels continue to rise. So if more hydrogen vehicles enter the market, the price of fossil fuels could decrease."
"Hydrogen vehicles are much quieter than fossil fuel vehicles. Thus, they can reduce noise pollution as well."
"If hydrogen escapes into the air, it can increase global warming."

"During the pandemic, social media helped people maintain their social lives.Social media has kept friends and loved ones in touch all the time. We can easily know what's going on in their lives. It allowed us to communicate with several people at the same time by sharing messages."

"Thanks to social media, we now have the opportunity to connect with many people, even if they don't live in our area. Before social media, we could interact with people in our locality or places where we go."

"By following friends on social networks and not communicating with them in private, we can only know the things they post on their accounts. Maybe we don't know much about what's really happening in their lives. This means that we will have no significant connection with friends. The ease of contacting people online made us prefer to meet them outside."

"Some people now have social anxiety because they don't have enough face-to-face interactions. When we avoid talking to people for a long time, we automatically develop a fear of participating in small speeches."
The troll on social media is a great threat. It affects the self-esteem of many people and also prevents them from creating social ties.

"In the book "iGen", it was mentioned that in the next decade we could see more young people who just know the right emoji for a situation  but not the right facial expression. This can become true if we prefer virtual life to real life."

"Thanks to close communities or micro-communities based on shared interests on social media as well as private messages, social media has given us the opportunity to establish real links with people we can really get closer to."
"The NEET exam standardizes the entry criteria for medical education across the country. As a high grade is required to enter government medical colleges, the exam ensures meritocracy."

"But every year, less than 20% of students take the exam. As a result, it is clear that the quality of medical education in other countries where Indian students are studying is not up to the standard of medical education in India. It is therefore very important to take steps to provide affordable and high-quality medical education in India."

"As the exam requires an additional study, the coaching centers take advantage of the situation and charge lakhs of rupees for coaching for the NEET exam. Therefore, because of this, students who cannot afford coaching are disadvantaged."

"Students work hard to score well in class 12 exams, but all this hard work is not recognized. And only the NEET score is considered for entry into the medical college, which is very unfair. In addition, the NEET exam is mainly based on the CBSE curriculum. So, students of the State Council need to study extra things to get a good mark on the exam."

"A high score at the NEET exam is required to obtain admission to government medical colleges in India. It costs about Rs.1.25 crores to study in private medical colleges in India. Thus, many students are forced to go to other countries such as China, Ukraine, Russia, the Philippines, etc. continue medical studies. In these countries, medical education costs around Rs.35 lakhs. In addition, they allow students with low NEET scores, but above the thresholds."

Some people on the moonlight to pursue their passion when the gains of their passion cannot replace the salary of their main work. Many entrepreneurs follow this path and leave their jobs once they earn enough from their new businesses.
"According to a study published by the Academy of Management Journal in 2021, the black moon can provide a sense of control and motivation, which can improve employee productivity."

"The sudden layoffs of several companies, especially during the pandemic, caused fear among many employees. And so several people took parallel concerts or a second job as a safety net in case they were fired."

Moonlight can help increase loss of life. Some people want to acquire new skills outside of what they work on in their main job. This can help them develop their expertise in their field. Some could get bored with monotonous jobs and thus take a second job to learn new skills and thus make their days exciting.
Companies fear the information and theft of sensitive data and the possibility of sharing it with their rival companies.

Some managers are concerned that moonlight employees may not be productive in their primary work due to fatigue and increased stress. There are also concerns about working for other companies during the office hours of my main job.

"In general, companies offer several advantages to employees, such as the contingency fund, health insurance, etc. Thus, they feel that this is unfair when their employees concentrate their energy and time on a second job, which does not bring any of these benefits."

A moneyless economy saves so much money for governments because printing and sending money to banks requires money and human resources. The need to purchase or lease land for ATMs will also be eliminated. International payments will also be easier because there is no need to exchange currencies.
Cashless transactions leave digital fingerprints of financial transactions. They can be used to trace illegal activities.
VOCID Pandemic has increased the number of cash-free transactions. They can prevent the spread of contagious diseases.

"Cashless transactions are registered by banks. Thus, the data will reveal people's critical data about where they spend money. The government can easily access data from anyone. This may result in mass monitoring programs. This runs counter to the right to privacy. Money gives us anonymity."
A moneyless economy will increase the number of cybercrimes.
Technical problems in the banking sector can stop access to our money. This can interfere with our daily lives.

"The refugees are forcibly displaced. They flee their country for a number of reasons, such as violence, human rights violations, war, persecution of minorities, etc. Often, they face threats to life in their home country. They leave their homes and everything else in search of a safer place to live."

"At present, many countries refuse refugees to declare that they pose a threat to the economy or security. Only a few countries, including Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey and Liberia, accept most refugees. Some host countries forcibly send refugees to their countries of origin, stating that the situation in their countries of origin is safe. Many refugees who have been sent like this have suffered brutal violence and some people have even disappeared."

All countries should share responsibility for refugees. Resettlement of refugees must take place without delay. They should be provided with refresher courses and employment opportunities to help them lead a dignified life.

"A weak global response worsens the situation of refugees. The international community should help rebuild war-torn countries, from which refugees came, so that safe and dignified returns were possible for refugees. Refugees should not be forcibly sent to their country of origin."
